description: From Middle English that, from Old English √æ√¶t (‚Äúthe, that‚Äù, neuter definite article and relative pronoun), from Proto-West Germanic *√æat, from Proto-Germanic *√æat. Cognate to Saterland Frisian d√§t, West Frisian dat, Dutch dat, Low German dat, German dass and das, Danish det, Swedish det, Icelandic √æa√∞, Gothic êå∏êå∞êçÑêå∞ (√æata).

entries.meaning: (degree) To a given extent or degree.
examples: "The ribbon was that thin." "I disagree, I say it was not that thin, it was thicker... or maybe thinner..."

entries.meaning: (degree) To a great extent or degree; very, particularly (in negative constructions).
examples: I did the run last year, and it wasn't that difficult.

entries.meaning: (informal, Britain, Australia) To such an extent; so. (in positive constructions).
examples: Ooh, I was that happy I nearly kissed her.

entries.meaning: (philosophy) Something being indicated that is there; one of those.
examples: As such, they do not have the ontological weight of "Being" and "Not-being," but serve simply as an explanatory vocabulary necessary to describe our world of thises and thats.
